clinical_study.brief_title: Reconstruction of Extensive Upper Extremity Long Bone Defects With a Microvascular Fibula Flap
clinical_study.official_title: Reconstruction of Extensive Upper Extremity Long Bone Defects With a Microvascular Fibula Flap: a Cross-sectional Study of Long-term Outcomes

brief_summary.textblock: This study assesses the long-term functional outcomes of upper extremity long bone defects treated with the free fibula bone transfer.

detailed_description.textblock: The study design entails a retrospective review of hospital records and a cross-sectional assessment using patient-reported outcome measures. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the reliability, complications and flap survival rate as well as the long-term functional and health-related quality of life results in patients with upper extremity long bone defect reconstructed using a microvascular fibula bone transfer.

primary_outcome.description: The long-term outcomes are assessed and good results gained.

secondary_outcome.measure: Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: Assesses the function of the reconstructed limb

secondary_outcome.measure: the 15-Dimensions health-related quality of life instrument
secondary_outcome.description: The 15-Dimensions assesses the health-related quality of life
Assesses the function of the donor site

intervention.description: Reconstructive surgery with a microvascular bone flap

study_pop.textblock: Twenty patients with upper extremity long bone bone defect treated with a microvascular fibula transfer. Population aged below 90 years.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients of upper extremity long bone bone defect treated with a microvascular fibula transfer in Helsinki University Central Hospital.
Exclusion Criteria:
- No upper extremity free fibular transfer
